article-meta.aff: 1The Hamlyn Centre for Robotic Surgery, Imperial College London, London, UK

author-notes.corresp: Mikael H. Sodergren, The Hamlyn Centre for Robotic Surgery, Imperial College London, Patterson Building (Level 3), Praed Street, London W2 1NY, UK Email: m.sodergren@imperial.ac.uk

abstract.p: Introduction. Since the first published work on natural orifice translumenal endoscopic surgery (NOTES) a decade ago, progress has been made in the domain of education and training, although questions posed by the original White Paper remain. This article aims to review the current status of education and training in NOTES. Methods. A review of the literature was conducted to evaluate the following: (1) What are the current training methods/modalities used for NOTES; what is the level of evidence to support their use? (2) How has NOTES clinical training been quantified; what is the evidence relating to performance of different NOTES operators? (3) What clinical NOTES training programs have been established and what are the wider training needs? Results. A total of 25 studies were included: 11 nonanimal studies, 8 animal studies, and 6 descriptions of education programs. Several animal and simulator models demonstrated construct validity, but no study showed human predictive validity. Logarithmic learning curves in animal models demonstrate 10 to 15 cases achieving a proficiency level. Current trends are that gastroenterologists prefer it for diagnostic and basic procedures, whereas surgeons prefer it for complex therapeutic cases. Conclusion. The development of a new specialty is intriguing but currently unviable. Training programs have been initiated, but information is limited; the common theme is surgeons receiving endoscopic training. Despite the research done, our knowledge of training and educating in NOTES procedures is limited, preventing a meta-analysis or formal review from being performed. Further research is needed to integrate NOTES into routine clinical procedure.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Since the first documentation of natural orifice translumenal endoscopic surgery (NOTES) in 2004 by Kalloo et al,1 there has been substantial progress, yet many of the original questions posed by the 2005 White Paper2 remain unanswered. In particular, issues regarding methods of education and training at both individual and collective levels further lead to questions regarding who is best suited to carry out NOTES procedures. Opinion at the time was largely in favor of multidisciplinary team–led procedures, combining skill sets from both gastroenterologists and gastrointestinal laparoscopic surgeons.

Driven by the possibility of fewer scars, less abdominal trauma, and possibly enhanced patient recovery, the field has seen a rapid expansion in interest and ideology. Indeed, looking at the scope of laparoscopic procedures available now since the very first studies almost 20 years ago,3 the possibilities for NOTES are likely to extend well beyond the current remit. This highlights the imminent need for a training pathway if NOTES is to have staying power as a credible and advantageous clinical option for individual procedures and patients in the future. The importance of this issue cannot be underestimated. Errors and misjudgments by surgeons can endanger patients’ lives,4 highlighting the need for extensive evaluation and research in NOTES prior to widespread implementation, particularly if the learning curve is similar to or steeper than that seen during the introduction of laparoscopic surgery.5-7

Any adjuncts used to augment training would thus undoubtedly be vital. Animal models, box trainers, and virtual reality simulators have been used successfully for many years in training surgeons in laparoscopic and endoscopic techniques and are continually evolving and becoming ever more sophisticated. In today’s surgical training, the use of simulators plays a key role, reflected by their use by the Society of American Gastrointestinal and Endoscopic Surgeons training in both laparoscopy and endoscopy.8
The aim of this article is to review current evidence relating to education and methods of training in NOTES and to evaluate the wider training needs and opportunities for future NOTES surgeons.

sec.title: Literature Search
sec.p: A review of all the published literature on education and training in NOTES was performed, with the aim of evaluating the following questions:

list-item.p: What are the current training methods and modalities in use for NOTES, and what is the level of evidence to support their use?
How has clinical training in NOTES been quantified, and what is the evidence relating to performance of NOTES operators of different skill sets and backgrounds?
What clinical NOTES training programs have been established and what are the future wider training needs?

sec.p: A comprehensive database search was undertaken using PubMed, MEDLINE (Ovid), EMBASE, and Google Scholar. Inclusion criteria included all original studies evaluating education and training modalities in NOTES, including those comparing proficiency of different NOTES operators. The search terms used were the following: natural orifice endoscopic surgery, simulation, training, virtual reality, box, education, and programme.

In PubMed, the following search algorithms were used: “(Natural Orifice Endoscopic Surgery) AND (simulation OR training OR virtual reality OR box)” and “(Natural Orifice Endoscopic Surgery) AND (surgeon OR gastroenterologists).” MESH terms included were education, endoscopy, and natural orifice endoscopic surgery.
Studies have been evaluated using the Oxford Centre for Evidence-based Medicine Levels of Evidence,9 commonly used for clinical trials.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: There were 25 studies included in this review, evaluating 11 nonanimal studies, 8 animal studies, and 6 descriptions of NOTES education and training programs. The majority of evidence supporting simulator use in NOTES education is on the ELITE (endoscopic-laparoscopic interdisciplinary training entity) phantom, with 5 reports on this box trainer system.

sec.title: What Are the Current Training Methods and Modalities in Use for NOTES, and What Is the Level of Evidence to Support Their Use?
ELITE Trainer
sec.p: The ELITE is an ex vivo model designed for endoscopic-laparoscopic and NOTES training. It is a full-scale replica of a human female adult with various translumenal abdominal access points (transesophageal, transgastric, and transrectal). The gastrointestinal tract and abdominal cavity are airtight, and other abdominal viscera are present to help simulate real operating conditions. The ELITE trainer is supported by 5 publications.

In the initial study by Gillen et al10 a mixture of novices, endoscopists, laparoscopists, and dual experts each received multiple cycles of training on the ELITE manikin. The task was to remove check marks placed in all 4 of the abdominal quadrants. A linear learning curve was shown with a significant reduction in overall time in all participants over subsequent attempts. The reduction in time taken was significant in endoscopic and laparoscopic novices but not in experts. The performance outcomes comparing endoscopic experts with novices demonstrate construct validity of the phantom. Participants were additionally assessed on a Likert scale, with results indicating that training on the ELITE makes sense, is realistic, is recommendable, is suitable for further skill assessment, improves NOTES skills, and improves endoscopic skills, thus demonstrating face and content validity of the simulator.

In the second study by Gillen et al,11 performance in a simulated transsigmoidal cholecystectomy of novices and endoscopic and laparoscopic experts was compared between those who had received training on the ELITE and a control group who had no training. Results showed the trained group to have a significantly shorter operative time, suggesting predictive validity on the simulator. There was no significant training effect in laparoscopists. The fact that novices were overall faster than endoscopists (although not statistically significant), yet slower than laparoscopists suggests that the construct was biased toward laparoscopists. Face validity was again assessed using a Likert scale, with all participants recommending the ELITE model and suggesting that it improved NOTES skills.

The study by Clark et al12 compared NOTES navigation between novices and endoscopic experts. Novices took significantly longer to complete the task supporting construct validity of the ELITE simulator. Analysis of the hand movements was also carried out based on video tracking and graded on a scale of 0 to 9 (9 implying most control and 0 erratic behavior), with experts scoring 7 and novices 6.

Sodergren et al13 used the ELITE manikin to perform navigation to the appendix and gallbladder, diathermy of the appendix base and gallbladder fossa, and clipping of the cystic duct during the investigation of horizon stabilization software. No overall significant improvement was shown, and there was no learning curve demonstrated.

The final ELITE study reported was by Fiolka et al.14 However, in this case, the phantom was adjusted with a cotton sponge layer integrated into organs as a dissection layer. Organ shift secondary to respiration was also introduced. Surgeons of varying grades participated in NOTES cholecystectomies, and a Likert scale graded 1 to 6 was used to assess face and content validity. In all aspects, the ELITE model was graded either 5 or 6, with only materials being found as satisfactory (graded as 3).

sec.title: Box Trainers
sec.p: Five box trainer simulators for NOTES were evaluated in the literature.15-19 Spaun et al15 used a simple training box (36 × 28 × 15 cm3), with endoscopes passed through “structural holes,” providing stability. The bimanual task consisted of grasping a rubber ring from a Sea Spikes Pod (a small bowl-shaped object with flexible rubber cones of differing lengths, shapes, and colors), transferring between instruments and replacing on another spike. The 27 participants were a mixture of experts (surgeons with >7 years endoscopy and laparoscopy experience) and novices (surgeons with <7 years endoscopy experience/NOTES lab experience only). Three different endoscopes were trialed with the same task, and overall, experts were significantly faster than novices, implying construct validity of the simulator. However, it should be noted that of the 3 different endoscopes used with the same task (a nonproduction R-Scope [Olympus], Direct Drive Endoscopic System [Boston Scientific], and a standard a dual-channel endoscope [Olympus]), the difference between experts and novices was only significant for the dual-channel endoscope.

Spaun et al16 used a bench-top trainer to further compare the EndoSAMURAI platform from Olympus with the standard dual-channel endoscope. As opposed to the previous box trainer study, this used a trainer with a structural hole 12 cm from the target. Participants were 2 novices, 7 intermediates, and 3 experts (surgeons with endoscopic, laparoscopic, and NOTES experience). The tasks were picking pins and dropping inside a small door and suturing. They compared 2 tasks and found the newer EndoSAMURAI platform to be significantly faster and more accurate (number of pins dropped and reliability of suture). Experts showed faster times in both tasks compared with the other groups, and the intermediates showed faster times than the novices, indicating a degree of construct validity; however, neither difference was statistically significant.

Thompson et al17 performed a study to evaluate the use of the Direct Drive Endoscopic System mentioned previously in NOTES procedures with laparoscopic and endoscopic experts involved. A bench-top model of a sphere with dots placed on it was initially used to evaluate movement of the platform, followed by a similar trial as mentioned before with the Sea Spikes Pod. This was followed by endoscopic mucosal resection from 2 ex vivo porcine stomachs. Finally, a transcolonic NOTES exploration was performed on a live porcine model, with suturing and knot tying. It is documented that a learning curve “was evident with all prescribed tasks,” with accuracy and speed improving after repetition.

Wagner et al18 used a box trainer designed and constructed by them but not further described in the study. The speed of performing tasks of picking up items and placing them in different locations was compared between novices, gastroenterologists, and laparoscopists. The first task assessed maneuverability, the second was to pick up a swab and place it in a basket, and the third was to pick up a swab and place it on a shelf. They found novices to be significantly worse than both endoscopy and laparoscopy experts in all tasks, supporting construct validity of the box trainer. In addition, linear learning curves were found for all tasks.

Finally, the natural orifice simulated surgical environment (NOSsE), a converted box trainer for NOTES simulation was originally described by Clark et al.20 The NOSsE is described as a standard laparoscopic training box adapted with access points through the box itself and lumenal organs contained inside it simulated from liquid latex and solid organs made with foam filler.20 James et al19 compared the speed at which novices and endoscopic experts navigated the NOSsE cavity using a flexible endoscope. Experts showed increased performance during this task, viewing the selected targets significantly more often in the set time, supporting construct validity of the NOSsE.

sec.title: In vivo models
sec.p: Gillen et al11 compared novices, surgeons, and endoscopists performing in vivo porcine cholecystectomies following training on the ELITE model mentioned previously. As mentioned, results showed the trained group to have a significantly shorter operative time, suggesting construct validity of the ELITE. It was also found that overall (with and without training), surgeons were faster than novices and endoscopists in porcine cholecystectomy. An objective view of each group’s intraoperative performance using a Likert scale showed the trained group to be better, but this did not reach statistical significance.

Fowler et al21 used equal numbers of experienced laparoscopists and gastroenterologists in live in vivo porcine models to visualize and touch 4 different abdominal sites in 2 separate cycles. The participants were randomized to 2 different spatial orientation devices, using one or the other on each cycle. The overall mean time to complete the task decreased significantly from first to second attempts, suggesting another linear learning curve, although there was no significant difference when comparing the improvements seen between staff grades and senior residents.

Freeman et al22,23 studied NOTES ovariectomies in an in vivo trial with 20 dogs by a trained gastroenterologist and a veterinary surgeon with laparoscopic experience. The first 10 dogs were used for a feasibility study.22 The mean operative times dropped significantly, compared with the first 5 procedures for the second 5 and the final 10, with a 3-factor exponential equation being produced to fit the learning curve.23 It was found that 10 procedures were required for the operative time to be within the 95% confidence interval for the time at an infinite procedure number. This study supports construct validity of the animal model.

Lomanto et al24 performed 5 successive porcine transvaginal abdominal wall hernia repairs. The procedures were conducted by gastroenterologists and surgeons, with operative times decreasing from 93 to 52 minutes; however, no statistical information was provided, and no documentation of the learning curve was made.

Fuchs et al25 performed transgastric procedures in 10 swine models, including fallopian tube ligation, cholecystectomy, cardiomyotomy, and small bowel resection. The team consisted of 2 surgeons with laparoscopic and endoscopic expertise as well as 1 gastroenterologist and 1 surgical resident. Learning curves were found for all procedures, measured by the time taken, with substantial reductions occurring after 5 cases.

Fuchs et al26 next described laparoscopic-assisted NOTES transgastric bowel resection and anastomoses in 13 live pigs. The operations were performed by a group of unspecified surgeons. The pigs, of different weights, were split into 2 groups operated 6 months apart. Operative times were shown to decrease in both groups.

Kavic et al27 used 5 live pigs over a 7-month period to perform NOTES-simulated appendectomies using fallopian tube models. Laparoscopic and endoscopic experts were involved. Laparoscopy was used to monitor the NOTES procedure and assist with hybrid tasks. A steep learning curve was encountered, especially in gaining access to the peritoneal cavity, with the time taken diminishing from 4 to 5 hours down to less than 1 hour.

sec.title: Ex vivo models
sec.p: Becerra Garcia et al28 used porcine livers and gallbladders embedded in an ex vivo trainer based on the Tuebingen Trainer (Richard Wolf GmbH, Knittlingen, Germany), with 3 laparoscopic surgeons performing around 30 cholecystectomies each. Logarithmic learning curves were demonstrated for all 3 participants, with a plateau after 15 cases. However, only for the intermediately experienced surgeon (75-100 laparoscopic cholecystectomies) was there a significant reduction in operative time between the initial 10 procedures and final 10.

sec.title: Virtual reality
sec.p: Minimal work regarding virtual reality simulators in NOTES has been carried out, with a prototype made by Korzeniowski et al29 demonstrating basic face validity.

sec.title: How Has Clinical Training in NOTES Been Quantified, and What Is the Evidence Relating to Performance of NOTES Operators of Different Skill Sets and Backgrounds?
sec.p: With regard to comparisons between gastroenterologists and surgeons, Table 1 shows the 5 studies included. In the first study by Gillen et al,10 gastroenterologists were found to be faster at the check marker task compared with surgeons in the first and fifth attempts. However, in the later study by Gillen et al11 that analyzed porcine cholecystectomies, surgeons were faster to complete the task compared with gastroenterologists. Following training, even novices were faster than gastroenterologists (average time = 59.8 and 80.4 minutes, respectively).

caption.p: Studies Comparing NOTES Performances Between Gastroenterologists and Surgeons.

tr.td: 10 Novices, 11 endoscopists (minimum 1 per year), 3 laparoscopists, 6 dual endoscopic/laparoscopic experts; total n = 30
Transanal-transsigmoidal locating and removing check marks representing 4 abdominal quadrants, 5 cycles, time taken to complete task

Gastroenterologists were significantly faster than surgeons in the first and fifth cycles. Endoscopy experts were significantly faster in the first run compared with novices (P = .041) and remained faster in the fifth run, although the difference was not significant (P = .161). Endoscopy and laparoscopy novices improved their times significantly by the final cycle (P = .041 and .02)
Gastroenterologists shown to be better at this simple task. However, significant improvements seen by endoscopy and laparoscopy novices
10 Novices, 10 experienced laparoscopists (>100), 10 experienced endoscopists (>100), equally split into 2 groups of 15; total n = 30
Transsigmoidal NOTES cholecystectomy on ELITE manikin, 4 cycles, followed by porcine cholecystectomy

Training effect seen in novices and endoscopists (P = .035 and.006) but not in laparoscopists (P = .235). Times of porcine cholecystectomy reduced by 22.4 and 24.8 minutes in laparoscopists and novices, respectively, but only by 5.4 minutes in endoscopists. Overall, surgeons were faster (mean = 60.6 minutes) than endoscopists (mean = 83.1 minutes)
Surgeons were fastest in performing the porcine cholecystectomy
Diathermy of appendix base, gallbladder fossa, and clipping of cystic duct; time taken for task completion and errors. 2 cycles, second randomized to horizon stabilization
In the first attempt gastroenterologists were significantly faster (P = .026), with no significant difference in errors made. In the second attempt, there were no difference in time or errors made
Gastroenterologists are innately better suited to basic NOTES procedures, but surgeons may rapidly improve to comparable levels
11 Novices, 7 gastroenterologists (>200 endoscopies), 12 laparoscopists (>100 procedures); total n = 30
3 Tasks: (1) maneuverability, (2) picking a swab and placing in a basket, (3) picking and placing swab on a shelf; time taken for task completion

Gastroenterologists were faster in all tasks, but there were no significant differences. Improvements were seen by repetition, but gastroenterologists showed no improvement in task 3, whereas surgeons showed a significant improvement (P = .003)
Gastroenterologists similar to surgeons in easier tasks, whereas surgeons show rapid improvements in more complex tasks
6 Experienced laparoscopists and 6 experienced gastroenterologists (200 endoscopic procedures); total n = 12
Time taken to visualize and touch 4 different intra-abdominal sites in 2 separate cycles (gallbladder, fallopian tube, a clip on the lower abdominal wall, and liver edge)
No significant difference between surgeons and gastroenterologists was found

fn.p: Abbreviations: NOTES, natural orifice translumenal endoscopic surgery; ELITE, endoscopic-laparoscopic interdisciplinary training entity.

sec.p: Sodergren et al13 used the ELITE manikin to compare gastroenterologists and surgeons in performing navigation to the appendix and gallbladder, diathermy of the appendix and gallbladder fossa, and clipping of the cystic duct. In the first cycle, gastroenterologists performed the tasks significantly faster, with no difference in errors made. There was no significant difference at all at the second attempt.

In the tasks set by Wagner et al18 mentioned previously, there were no significant differences between surgeons and gastroenterologists; however, surgeons showed a significant improvement in the final task. This may have been the most challenging task because it involved maneuvering the scope and grasping an object and then maneuvering the scope with the object to a distant location.

Fowler et al21 evaluated the time taken to identify and touch 4 set sites (the gallbladder, the fallopian tube, a clip placed on the lower abdominal wall, and the liver edge) in a porcine model. They did not find any significant differences between general surgeons and gastroenterologists.

sec.title: What Clinical NOTES Training Programs Have Been Established, and What Are the Future Wider Training Needs?
Courses
sec.p: Significant training programs have been set up at the Research Institute against Digestive Cancer, European Institute of Telesurgery center in Strasbourg, France,30 with 500 people having attended nonspecified hands-on training between 2007 and 2010, of which 20% were gastroenterologists. In the United Kingdom, the first NOTES training course was in 2008 at the University of Surrey.31 Live surgery was shown as well as lectures and hands-on training on porcine tissues. The procedures covered in hands-on training were laparoscopy, gastrotomy with needle knife, transgastric peritoneoscopy, transgastric or transvaginal cholecystectomy, gastrotomy closure and laparotomy, and assessment of closure. A 2-day hands-on NOTES course is also available at the World Laparoscopy Hospital in Delhi, India.32 Cholecystectomy and appendectomy are covered as well as a variety of approaches.

sec.title: Residency programs and fellowships
sec.p: Kavic et al,27 as previously mentioned, initialized a NOTES training program for surgical residents at the University of Ohio. Five large farm swine were used in large animal laboratories sessions, with anterior wall gastrotomies used to access the abdominal cavity to perform laparoscopic-assisted simulated appendectomies, using fallopian tube models. The work was led by both laparoscopic surgeons and endoscopists, giving combined teaching.

Morales et al33 looked at increasing the amount of endoscopic experience surgical residents at the University of Missouri received. An initial audit found that chief residents graduated with an average of 43 endoscopy cases; this was increased to 161 by having at least 1 resident present in the biweekly endoscopy days at the VA hospital.

Joseph Elmunzer, a gastroenterology trainee described his experience34 on a “mini-fellowship,” where he spent time at the Case Medical Center Cleveland, Ohio. He describes time spent in animal laboratory experiments (35%), observing human surgery and attending conferences (20%), nonlaboratory research time (35%), and other miscellaneous educational activities (10%). Though anecdotal, he describes the benefit of working with surgeons to develop his NOTES skills. Levels of evidence for all studies are documented in Table 2.

caption.p: Levels of Evidence for All Studies Included in the Review.

tr.td: Cross-sectional study: construct validation of ELITE model using novices and experts
Randomized control trial: comparing whether intervention with training on the ELITE model benefitted performance in a porcine NOTES cholecystectomy
Cross-sectional study: further construct validation of the ELITE
Cohort study: comparison between gastroenterologists and surgeons
Cross-sectional study: face validation of the ELITE
Cross-sectional study: construct validation of a box trainer using novices and experts
Cross-sectional study: construct validation of a bench-top trainer and endoscopy device using novices and experts
Anecdotal evidence of learning curves seen in experts using a bench-top practice with a box trainer
Cross-sectional study: construct validation of a self-designed box with tasks done by experts and novices
Cross-sectional study: construct validation of ELITE model using novices and experts
Cross-sectional study: showing significant improvements in performances on live porcine models with experienced laparoscopists and gastroenterologists
Cohort study: 1 team of experts performing multiple canine procedures showing a decrease in operating time
Cohort study: 1 team of experts performing multiple canine procedures showing a decrease in operating time
Cohort study: 1 team of experts performing multiple porcine procedures showing a decrease in operating time
Cohort study: a single team of experts performed multiple operations and types on a porcine model showing a decrease in operating time
Cohort study: a single team of experts performed multiple operations and types on a porcine model showing a decrease in operating time
Cohort study: a single team of experts performed multiple operations on a porcine model showing a decrease in operating time
Cohort study: 3 surgeons performed NOTES cholecystectomies on porcine livers embedded into the Tuebingen Trainer showing a decrease in operating time
Cross-sectional study: face validation of a NOTES virtual reality simulator by expert surgeons
Audit of endoscopic experience in trainees and subsequent increased endoscopic training time

fn.p: Abbreviations: ELITE, endoscopic-laparoscopic interdisciplinary training entity; NOTES, natural orifice translumenal endoscopic surgery.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: There appears to have been a rapid expansion of NOTES procedures worldwide, with the number of registered cases in Germany alone being more than 2000 at the time of writing.35 However, the number of institutions and surgeons performing NOTES may not have increased substantially. Several international committees and conferences have also been set up, such as the EURO-NOTES Foundation36 and the Natural Orifice Surgery Consortium for Assessment and Research (NOSCAR).37 However, the original questions posed by the 2005 White Paper have limited answers. Current training in NOTES is minimal at best, further limited by a lack of new endoscopic technologies. Overall, NOTES currently only plays a fringe role in everyday clinical practice, with the majority of surgeons considering NOTES to still be very much experimental.

Two main categories of training have been evaluated—animal models and box trainers (either actual boxes or simulated abdominal cavities)—with some studies using a combination of both. Some of the box trainers and tasks used are shown in Figure 1. Frequently, the descriptions of box trainers are poorly documented and, therefore, have limited reproducibility.

caption.p: A. The NOSsE trainer. B. Internal view of the NOSsE. C. The ELITE manikin. D. Internal view of the ELITE. E. The Sea Spikes Pod38
Abbreviations: NOSsE, natural orifice simulated surgical environment; ELITE, endoscopic-laparoscopic interdisciplinary training entity.

sec.p: Despite the large quantity of work produced looking at simulators and animal models in NOTES, there are no studies that show true evidence of concurrent and predictive validity for human NOTES. Furthermore, most studies evaluating construct validity use endoscopic and/or laparoscopic proficiency as markers of experience, when strictly speaking this should be NOTES experience; however, this may be understandable because the global number of true human NOTES experts is very small.

The well-documented ELITE model has shown repeated demonstrations of construct, face, and content validity.10,11,14 Learning curves were demonstrated; however, they were not significant for laparoscopic surgeons. The significant improvements seen from using the ELITE trainer on porcine cholecystectomies (arguably the most realistic human model apart from cadavers) provides the strongest evidence of predictive validity of the trainer. Other box-type trainers, although less sophisticated, can simulate important NOTES skills. Spaun et al15 and Wagner et al18 found that endoscopy and laparoscopy experts performed significantly better with shorter task times than novices, suggesting validity of the respective box trainers. Between the ELITE trainer and the simple box trainers mentioned above is the NOSsE, which James et al19 showed to have construct validity for a NOTES navigation task.

Animal models, especially porcine, appear well suited for NOTES training; however, there is currently no evidence that either box simulations or animal training has either concurrent or predictive validity in human NOTES. Once this is achieved, we can ascertain prehuman operative proficiency levels, which can help strive toward a validated simulator, which is cheap, easily available, and provides competency-based training. Statistically significant learning curves were found in several animal studies21,23,28; a lack of statistical support in others makes drawing conclusions from their data difficult.24,25 Hence although NOTES training can be shown to have a measurable impact on some well-defined skills, there is no evidence to show that this improves the operative performance in patients. At this stage of evolution, perhaps, only the most experienced laparoscopic surgeon or endoscopist will want to trial NOTES. The training methods evaluated may help form a program for such candidates, rather than for junior trainees. Several training programs have been set up to incorporate NOTES. The basis of these is that surgeons get minimal experience in endoscopy during their training. The NOTES training at present appears to be endoscopy focused,33 usually led by laparoscopists and endoscopists. Current NOTES training at our institution is based on a mixture of box simulation,20 ex vivo simulation in particular, with robotics work and in vivo work. The box simulation work uses our in-house designed NOSsE trainer, with the phantom abdominal cavity being used for practicing NOTES maneuvering techniques and visualizations and replacement of various intra-abdominal viscera with animal ones to replicate procedures.

In comparing surgeons with gastroenterologists, overall 3 out of the 4 studies found gastroenterologists to be faster (although only 2 were statistically significant10,13) at simple tasks. However, greater improvements were seen in surgeons,11,13,18 and in the porcine cholecystectomy comparison,11 surgeons were indeed faster. Confounding errors may occur where surgeons may also be dual-endoscopic experts.10 However, overall, the limited data presented so far seem to indicate that gastroenterologists (endoscopists) have a “head-start” in simple NOTES tasks and navigation compared with surgeons; however, surgeons rapidly improve. With regard to more complicated procedures, surgeons appear to perform better, which is likely because of greater experience with the intra-abdominal cavity and viscera.

The issue of who should perform NOTES has in essence a simple answer: those who are best qualified to perform should do so. Gastroenterologists or gastrointestinal surgeons could be trained in both diagnostic and therapeutic NOTES procedures, or perhaps gastroenterologists could be preferred for diagnostic (including intensive care patients, patients with severe burns, and obesity) and basic procedures such as targeted tissue biopsy, whereas gastrointestinal surgeons could be preferred for more complex therapeutic cases where surgical skill and anatomical knowledge is essential. An even more tantalizing prospect is the rise of a new hybrid speciality.39,40 Indeed, development of new tools and machines may influence this hugely.

In Table 2, we can see that the majority of evidence has relatively weak foundations, with no class 1 evidence as yet available and few class 2 studies seen. This should be considered when designing further studies because the lack of high-quality research will hinder the development of the field.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Adding advanced endoscopic training to a surgical curriculum adds extra time and pressure to the already burdened trainee. Pushing further with NOTES may take many years of training, highlighting an issue in the undercurrent of all procedural specialties, where because of the rapid pace of change, a surgeon’s technical skills may become out of date within 5 to 10 years of completing training.8 Despite the research done, our knowledge of training and educating in NOTES procedures is limited, and hence a meta-analysis or formal review cannot be performed as yet.

Based on the findings of this article, it seems that individual NOTES training has a rapidly growing body of evidence, showing validity of various models. Simulators and animal models will continue to play a key role in NOTES training for years to come and may help develop techniques preclinically. Hybrid techniques currently used do not have suitable training schemes and fully NOTES training schemes are still at a premium, with few examples set worldwide. These would need to be expanded to educate the new generation of NOTES practitioners. However, uptake will be poor as long as technological limitations remain. It is possible that future NOTES surgeons will be subspecialty-trained surgeons with advanced endoscopic experience. However, further development of new instruments and technologies as well as the expansion of NOTES into other fields will undoubtedly affect the course NOTES takes in the future.
